prompt: Mark told Pete many lies about himself, which Pete included in his book. He should have been more skeptical.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Mark"? Explain your choice.

prompt: The mothers of Arthur and Celeste have come to the town to fetch them. They are very happy to have them back, but they scold them just the same because they ran away.  In the sentence above, does "them" refer to "mothers"? Explain your choice.
response: In this sentence, "them" refers to "mothers".   This is because "them" is a plural pronoun, and it is used to refer to a group of people, in this case, both "Arthur" and "Celeste". The sentence is saying that the mothers of both Arthur and Celeste have come to the town, so "them" is referring to the group of mothers, rather than just one mother.

prompt: Mark was close to Mr. Singer 's heels. He heard him calling for the captain, promising him, in the jargon everyone talked that night, that not one thing should be damaged on the ship except only the ammunition, but the captain and all his crew had best stay in the cabin until the work was over  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Mr. Singer"? Explain your choice.
response: The pronoun "He" in the sentence refers to "Mr. Singer".   The reason is that "He" is a subject pronoun, which is used to refer to a person who is performing an action or being addressed. In this case, the action is "promising" and the subject is "Mr. Singer".   The pronoun "He" is in the third person, indicating that it is referring to a person, specifically Mr. Singer, rather than a person in general or an abstract concept.

prompt: The pony behaved well, sir, and showed no vice; but at last he just threw up his heels and tipped the young gentleman into the thorn hedge. He wanted me to help him out, but I hope you will excuse me, sir, I did not feel inclined to do so.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "young gentleman"? Explain your choice.
response: In the given sentence, "He" refers to "the young gentleman".   The pronoun "he" is used as an object of the verb "to tip", indicating that the action of tipping the young gentleman is being performed on him. This is a common usage of the pronoun "he", which is a masculine pronoun in this context.  In this sentence, "he" is being used as a direct object, indicating that the action is being performed on the young gentleman.

prompt: I poured water from the bottle into the cup until it was full.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "the cup"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence "I poured water from the bottle into the cup until it was full," the pronoun "it" refers to "the cup." This is because "it" is a singular pronoun that refers to a single entity, in this case, the cup. When we say "I poured water from the bottle into the cup," "it" is the object of the preposition "from," indicating the action of pouring, which is taking place in the cup.  In contrast, if "it" were referring to the bottle, it would be an example of a pronoun that refers to a plural entity, which would not make sense in this context.

prompt: Dan had to stop Bill from toying with the injured bird. He is very compassionate.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Dan"? Explain your choice.

prompt: The city councilmen refused the demonstrators a permit because they advocated violence.  In the sentence above, does "they" refer to "The demonstrators"? Explain your choice.

prompt: After I saw Bill catching flies and pulling off their wings, I boxed his ears. prompt: Joan made sure to thank Susan for all the help she had given.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Susan"? Explain your choice.

prompt: Sir Clifford wants me to find him a new groom , about twenty or twenty-one, who knows his business. prompt: Fred covered his eyes with his hands , because the wind was blowing sand around. He lowered them when the wind stopped.  In the sentence above, does "them" refer to "His hands"? Explain your choice.

prompt: As Ollie carried Tommy up the long winding steps, his legs ached.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Ollie"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "his" refers to "Ollie".   The pronoun "his" is a possessive pronoun, meaning it shows that something belongs to Ollie. The word "his" is used to indicate that the subject of the sentence (Ollie) owns or possesses something, in this case, Tommy.  For example: "His car is red" means "the car belongs to him".  In the given sentence, "his" is used to show that Tommy is being carried by Ollie, making it clear that Tommy is a part of Ollie's physical presence.

prompt: Carol believed that Rebecca regretted that she had stolen the watch.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Rebecca"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, in the sentence "Carol believed that Rebecca regretted that she had stolen the watch," the pronoun "she" refers to "Rebecca."   The reason for this is that "she" is a possessive pronoun, which is used to indicate that the object belongs to the subject. In this context, "she" is referring to the watch, which is the object that Rebecca regrets having stolen. The possessive pronoun "her" would not make sense in this sentence because it would imply that the watch belongs to Rebecca, rather than that Rebecca has stolen it.

prompt: Bob paid for Charlie 's college education. He is very generous.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Charlie"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "He" refers to "Charlie". The pronoun "He" is a masculine pronoun and is used as the subject of the sentence. The context suggests that Bob is the one who paid for Charlie's college education, implying that he is the one who made the payment, and therefore "He" is referring to Charlie.

prompt: All the buttons up the back of Dora 's plaid dress were buttoned outside-in. Maude should have thought to button her up; but no, she had left poor little Dora to do the best she could, alone.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Dora"? Explain your choice.
response: The pronoun "she" in the sentence "Maude should have thought to button her up; but no, she had left poor little Dora to do the best she could, alone" refers to Dora.   This is because the subject of the sentence is "Dora", and in this case, it's a proper noun (a specific name), so it's not a pronoun referring to a general person, which is why "she" is used.

prompt: The table was piled high with food , and on the floor beside it there were crocks, baskets, and a five-quart pail of milk.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "floor"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "it" refers to "the table". This is because the word "it" is an indefinite pronoun, which is used to refer to a specific object or concept. In this case, "it" is clearly referring to the table, as it is the location where the food and other items are piled up.  The use of "it" here is also consistent with the context, as it is the object of the verb "was piled high with", indicating that the table is the location where the food and other items are stacked.

prompt: Mark was close to Mr. Singer 's heels. He heard him calling for the captain , promising him, in the jargon everyone talked that night, that not one thing should be damaged on the ship except only the ammunition, but the captain and all his crew had best stay in the cabin until the work was over.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Mark"? Explain your choice.
response: The pronoun "his" in the sentence refers to "Mr. Singer".   The reason for this choice is that "his" is a possessive form of the pronoun "he", which indicates that the speaker is referring to Mr. Singer, a person, as the subject of the sentence. Since Mark is close to Mr. Singer, it makes sense for Mark to be addressed as "his" to show a personal connection or familiarity with the person.

prompt: The man lifted the boy onto his shoulders.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "The boy"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "his" refers to "The boy". The pronoun "his" is a possessive pronoun, which means it shows that the subject (the boy) belongs to or has something. In this context, it indicates that the boy is being lifted onto the man's shoulders, which is a physical action that belongs to him.  So, "his" is a demonstrative pronoun, which is used to show that something belongs to a specific person. In this case, the boy belongs to the man, and the sentence is describing an action that is being done to him.

prompt: Do you suppose that Peter is responsible for the captain ’s illness? Maybe he bribed the cook to put something in his food.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Peter"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "his" refers to "Peter". The use of "his" as a possessive pronoun in this context indicates that Peter is the one who is doing something to the food, rather than "his" referring to the cook.   In English, "his" is used to show possession when the subject of the sentence is a noun that is being acted upon, as in the case of "his food". When the subject is the one doing the action, "his" is used to show that the action is directed towards the subject, which is Peter in this case.

prompt: The signs over the shops' doors had pictures that indicated what work was done inside. Although more and more people were learning how to read, each artisan still had signs, not wishing to lose a possible patron merely because he happened to be illiterate.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "patron"? Explain your choice.
response: The word "he" in the sentence "Although more and more people were learning how to read, each artisan still had signs, not wishing to lose a possible patron" refers to "patron".  The reason is that "he" is an object pronoun, which is used to refer to a person or thing. In this context, "he" is referring to a patron, meaning a customer or client of the shop.  The word "patron" is a noun that refers to a person who pays for goods or services, whereas "he" is a pronoun that refers to a person or thing.  The sentence is saying that the artisans are worried about losing customers, implying that they are concerned about their livelihoods. The use of "he" in this sentence emphasizes this concern, as it is a person, not an object.

prompt: Paul tried to call George on the phone, but he wasn't available.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "George"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "he" in the sentence refers to "George". The pronoun "he" is a subject pronoun, which is used to refer to a person performing an action. In this sentence, "he" is used to refer to the person who was trying to call George, indicating that George is the one performing the action of not being available on the phone.

prompt: Sam's drawing was hung just above Tina's and it did look much better with another one above it.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "Sam's drawing"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence "Sam's drawing was hung just above Tina's and it did look much better with another one above it," the pronoun "it" refers to "Sam's drawing". This is because "it" is a pronoun that refers to a noun in the sentence, specifically "Sam's drawing". The context indicates that "it" is describing or specifying "Sam's drawing", rather than "Tina's" drawing.

prompt: The table won't fit through the doorway because it is too wide.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "The table"? Explain your choice.
response: In this sentence, "it" refers to "The table".   The pronoun "it" is a pronoun that is used as a substitute for a noun, often a noun that is already known or can be easily identified. In this case, the context of the sentence is clear, as "it" is describing "The table", making it clear that "it" refers to the table.

prompt: Emma Emma's mother had died long ago, and her education had been managed by an excellent woman as governess.  In the sentence above, does "her" refer to "Emma's mother"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "her" refers to "Emma's mother". The word "her" is a possessive pronoun, which indicates that the subject of the sentence is Emma's mother.   "Her" is a possessive pronoun that shows ownership or possession, and it is used to indicate that the subject of the sentence is something that belongs to Emma. In this context, "her" refers to the fact that Emma's mother was the governess, meaning she was the one who managed Emma's education.

prompt: Bill passed the gameboy to John because his turn was next.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "John"? Explain your choice.
response: In this sentence, "his" refers to "John". The possessive form "his" is used to indicate that the object belongs to John.   In this context, "Bill passed the gameboy to John" means Bill gave the gameboy to John, implying that the gameboy is something that belongs to John, so "his" is used to show ownership.

prompt: Of one thing Mark was sure. Harry knew much less than he did.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Harry"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "he" refers to "Mark." This is because the pronoun "he" is typically used to refer to a male person, whereas "Harry" is a male name. In the context of the sentence, Mark is likely the male character being addressed, so "he" is used to refer to Mark.

prompt: Do you suppose that Peter is responsible for the captain ’s illness? Maybe he bribed the cook to put something in his food.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "the captain"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence "Do you suppose that Peter is responsible for the captain's illness? Maybe he bribed the cook to put something in his food," "his" refers to "the captain".   The word "his" is a possessive pronoun, which indicates that something belongs to Peter. In this case, "his" is referring to the captain, as in "the captain's illness".

prompt: What about the time you cut up tulip bulbs in the hamburgers because you thought they were onions?  In the sentence above, does "they" refer to "hamburgers"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "they" refers to "onions." This is an example of a pronoun reference error, also known as a pronoun ambiguity.   The choice of "they" is ambiguous because the sentence is using the pronoun "they" to refer to "onions" instead of "hamburgers." This is a result of the sentence structure and the context in which the pronoun is used.  In the original sentence, "I thought they were onions" implies that the speaker is referring to a group of people, likely a group of people eating hamburgers, and the speaker believes they are actually onions. However, by using the pronoun "they," the sentence is shifting the focus to a different group of people, which is the people eating hamburgers.

prompt: Fred covered his eyes with his hands , because the wind was blowing sand around. He lowered them when the wind stopped.  In the sentence above, does "them" refer to "His eyes"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "them" refers to "his eyes". This is because the subject of the sentence is "Fred", and the pronoun "them" is used to refer to Fred, indicating that the action of covering his eyes is something he is doing in relation to himself.  If "them" were to refer to something else, it would change the context and make the sentence grammatically incorrect.

prompt: Sid explained his theory to Mark but he couldn't understand him.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Sid"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "he" refers to "Mark."   The pronoun "he" is a third-person singular pronoun, which is used to refer to a person who is male or non-binary. Since "Mark" is a male name, the pronoun "he" is being used to refer to him, indicating that Sid is the one speaking.

prompt: Tom gave Ralph a lift to school so he wouldn't have to drive alone.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Ralph"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence "Tom gave Ralph a lift to school so he wouldn't have to drive alone," the pronoun "he" refers to "Ralph."   This is because "he" is an objective pronoun, which refers to a person or a thing that exists independently of the speaker. In this context, "he" is used to describe Tom giving a lift to Ralph, indicating that the action is a result of Tom's action (giving the lift). The pronoun "he" does not depend on the speaker, so it is referring to the person performing the action, which is Tom.

prompt: When my parents died, I was not earning enough to keep myself or my crippled sister Nelly , and without our kind mistress , we would have gone to the poorhouse. Nelly calls her her angel and she has good right to do so. her  In the sentence above, does "her" refer to "mistress"? Explain your choice.
response: In this sentence, "her" refers to "mistress".   The pronoun "her" is a possessive pronoun, which means it shows ownership or relationship. In this context, "her" is used to indicate that Nelly is referring to the mistress, implying that she is the one who is being referred to as an "angel". The word "mistress" is an object of the possessive pronoun "her", meaning it is the object of Nelly's affection and respect.

prompt: After I saw Bill catching flies and pulling off their wings, I boxed his ears. I showed the master the flies, some crushed and some crawling about helpless, and I showed him the wings on the window sill. I never saw him so angry before; but as Bill was still howling and whining, like the coward that he was, he did not give him any more punishment of that kind, but set him up on a stool for the rest of the afternoon, and said that he should not go out to play for that week.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "the master"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "he" refers to "Bill".   The reason is that the sentence structure is "after I saw Bill catching flies and pulling off their wings, I showed the master the flies, some crushed and some crawling about helpless, and I showed him the wings on the window sill." Here, "Bill" is a subject performing an action (catching flies and pulling off their wings), and "he" is the object of the action (the master). The use of "he" is a masculine pronoun, which is consistent with the male subject performing the action.

prompt: After I saw Bill catching flies and pulling off their wings, I boxed his ears. I showed the master the flies, some crushed and some crawling about helpless, and I showed him the wings on the window sill. I never saw him so angry before; but as Bill was still howling and whining, like the coward that he was, he did not give him any more punishment of that kind, but set him up on a stool for the rest of the afternoon, and said that he should not go out to play for that week.  In the sentence above, does "him" refer to "the master"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "him" refers to "the master". The pronoun "him" is a reflexive pronoun, which is used to refer back to the person or people affected by an action, in this case, the master.  The reason for this choice is that "him" is the indirect object of the sentence, and in this case, it is the master who is the direct object of the verb "showed". The sentence is saying that the master showed the flies to the speaker, and then showed them to Bill, and so on. The master is the one being referred to by "him".  This usage of "him" is a common way to refer to the person affected by an action in a sentence, and it is often used in informal writing and speech. In formal writing, it's generally safer to use "the master" instead, as it is more direct and clear.  In the original sentence, using "him" instead of "the master" would change the intended meaning, as it would imply that the master was the one being referred to by "him", rather than the person being addressed.

prompt: Ann asked Mary what time the library closes, because she had forgotten.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Mary"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence "Ann asked Mary what time the library closes," "she" refers to "Mary".   This is because the subject of the sentence is "Mary", and the pronoun "she" is used to refer to Mary. The pronoun "she" is a third-person singular pronoun that is used to refer to a female person, in this case, Mary.
